Alex,

Thanks for letting us know.  JUnit 4.4 does include method annotations
in the Description, which should help one of your frustrations.  Were
you using the default JUnit that ships with Eclipse (currently 4.3.1)?

It sounds like you also wanted to allow users to register a listener
regardless of how the tests were run, which TestNG does with a
command-line parameter, and JUnit currently does not support.  This
sounds like a valuable feature--is a command-line parameter the ideal
way to do it?

The default runners for JUnit classes should be out of "internal"
status soon.  We focused first on making it possible to run any
conceivable set of tests from JUnit, especially crazy stuff (such as
Ruby tests: http://johlrogge.wordpress.com/2007/09/08/hybrid-theory/).
 A major focus of 4.5 is making it easier to make finer-grained
extensions to JUnit's built-in runners, without touching internals.

One more favor--can you explain how FEST currently was capturing
screenshots from JUnit, and why that didn't work when running tests
from Eclipse?

Thanks again,

   David Saff
